abstract.text: The iOS interface environment for your app, including traits such as horizontal and vertical size class, display scale, and user interface idiom.
The force touch capability value of the trait collection.
A set of methods that makes the iOS interface environment available to your app.
Keys that indicate the availability of 3D Touch on a device.
The iOS interface environment for your app, including traits such as horizontal and vertical size class, display scale, and user interface idiom.
The horizontal size class of the trait collection.
The vertical size class of the trait collection.
The display scale of the trait collection.
The user interface idiom of the trait collection.
Constants that indicate the interface type for the device or an object that has a trait environment, such as a view and view controller.
Constants that indicate the size class of a view.
A set of methods for adapting the contents of your view controllers to size and trait changes.

media-2957521.alt: Examples of size classes on iOS devices. The top figures show the size classes for a 10.5 inch iPad as horizontally and vertically regular. For an iPhone X, the vertical size class in a portrait orientation is regular, but all of the other size classes are compact.

abstract.text: Creates a trait collection that consists of traits merged from a specified array of trait collections.
Creates a trait collection whose traits are set to their default (unspecified) values.
Creates a trait collection that contains only a specified interface idiom.
Creates a trait collection that contains only a specified horizontal size class.
Creates a trait collection that contains only a specified vertical size class.
Creates a trait collection that contains only the specified user interface style trait.
Creates a trait collection that contains only the specified accessibility contrast trait.
Creates a trait collection that contains only the specified user interface level trait.
Creates a trait collection that contains only the specified legibility weight trait.
Creates a trait collection that contains only a specified force touch capability trait.
Creates a trait collection that contains only a specified display scale.
Creates a trait collection that contains only the specified display gamut trait.
Creates a trait collection that contains only the specified layout direction trait.
Creates a trait collection that contains only the specified content size category trait.
Creates a trait collection that contains only the specified active appearance trait.
Creates a trait collection from data in an unarchiver.
The complete set of traits for the current environment.
The gamut of the current display.
Constants that indicate the gamut of the current display.
The style associated with the user interface.
Constants that indicate the interface style for the app.
The elevation level of the interface.
Constants that indicate the visual level for content in the window.
The layout direction associated with the current environment.
Constants that indicate the layout direction associated with the current environment.
The accessibility contrast associated with the current environment.
Constants that indicate the accessibility contrast setting.
The font weight to apply to text.
Constants that indicate the weight to apply to text in your interface.
A property that indicates whether the user interface has an active appearance.
Constants that indicate whether the user interface has an active appearance.
The font sizing option preferred by the user.
Constants that indicate the preferred size of your content.
Compares two content size category values to determine whether they are equal or whether one is larger than the other.
Returns a Boolean value that indicates whether the content size category belongs to the group of accessibility-related sizes.
Queries whether a trait collection contains all of another trait collection’s values.
Queries whether changing between the specified and current trait collections would affect color values.
An image configuration object compatible with this trait collection.
Executes custom code using the traits of the current trait collection.

abstract.text: Change images and resources dynamically when the screen gamut on your device changes.
A set of methods that, in conjunction with a presentation controller, determine how to respond to trait changes in your app.

inlineContent.text: The iOS trait environment is exposed though the
property of the
protocol. This protocol is adopted by the following classes:
, and
. To create an adaptive interface, write code to adjust your app’s layout according to changes in these traits. You access specific trait values using the
, and
properties. The values that express idiom and size traits are defined in the
and
enumerations; the value for the display scale trait is expressed as a floating point number.
To make your view controllers and views responsive to changes in the iOS interface environment, override the
method from the trait environment protocol. To customize view controller animations in response to interface environment changes, override the
method of the
protocol.
shows the horizontal (width) and vertical (height) size classes your app can encounter when running on various devices fullscreen.

You can create standalone trait collections to assist in matching against specific environments. The
class includes four specialized constructors as well as a constructor that lets you combine an array of trait collections,
One important use of standalone trait collections is to enable conditional use of images based on the current iOS interface environment. You can associate a trait collection with a
instance by way of a
instance, as described in the overview section of
. For information on configuring asset catalogs graphically from within the Xcode IDE, see Asset Catalog Help.
You can employ a standalone trait collection to enable a two-column split view in landscape orientation on iPhone. See the
method of the
class.
A standalone trait collection is also useful in customizing view appearance, by way of the
protocol method, as described in
Starting in iOS 9, you can use this class to check whether the device on which your app is running supports 3D Touch. Read the value of the
property on the trait collection for any object in your app with a trait environment. For information about trait environments, see
. For the possible values of the force touch capability property, see the
enumeration.
Because a user can turn off 3D Touch in Settings, check the value of the
property in your implementation of the
method, and adjust your code paths according to the property’s value.
